claim: Amy Cuddy's power poses experiments establish the fundamental principle that individuals feel more powerful when they stand in a pose associated with power.

supporting.text: Amy Cuddy's original 2010 study demonstrated that adopting high-power poses increased self-reported feelings of power and risk tolerance.

attacks.text: Amy Cuddy's original 2010 study demonstrated that adopting high-power poses increased self-reported feelings of power and risk tolerance.
Subsequent replication attempts failed to reproduce Cuddy's findings, casting doubt on the robustness of the power pose effect.
Many replication studies had smaller sample sizes and methodological differences, which could explain their failure to replicate the original effect.
The original study relied on self-reported measures, which are subjective and prone to bias, rather than objective behavioral indicators of power.
Self-reported measures are commonly used in psychology and can provide valid insights into subjective experiences like feelings of power.
The power pose effect may be context-dependent and not universally applicable, as cultural differences in body language can influence the results.
